Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Low power hardware-software subsystem for intelligent sensory stream analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to significantly reduce the development effort for continuous sensing applications and to enable deploying them in a wide range of battery-constrained sensing devices, including personal mobile devices like smartphones, tablets, and smart watches; wearable health monitoring devices for tracking EKG/EEG and other vital signals; and remote sensing devices for monitoring structural integrity, emission levels, pollutant concentrations, or seismic data. In these applications, continuous sensing triggers context- and location-aware computation or communication in response to sensory stimuli in the device?s environment. Without dramatic innovations in the development of ultra-low power sensory processing, continuous sensing will remain a niche application limited to environments with a stable and plentiful power source. In contrast, this project will demonstrate the viability and potential widespread deployment of continuous sensing in mobile and remote environments. The ability to flexibly deploy continuous sensing for these and other applications has the potential to revolutionize these markets and create entirely new and unforeseen application domains, dramatically altering the extent to which cyber-physical systems can interact with their physical environments.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 2 project will develop a complete software and hardware platform for developing and deploying applications that identify and respond to spatial and temporal trigger signatures (events of interests) in continuous sensory data streams. Current sensory processing platforms rely on a power-hungry application processor to analyze continuous sensory streams of real world phenomena to identify trigger signatures, and application development is cumbersome and requires significant domain expertise. The proposed approach offloads continuous sensing and trigger signature detection from the power-hungry application processor to a recognition engine deployed either in firmware on a low-power microcontroller or as a custom hardware accelerator. Furthermore, an integrated software development toolkit will be provided to streamline implementation of sophisticated sensing applications, leading to widespread adoption and future availability of always-on, sensor-based applications. The result of this project will be a software implementation of the novel neurally-inspired algorithm/firmware optimized to be deployed on currently available smartphones, a software toolkit that enables easy and rapid development of always-on sensing applications, and a novel ultra low power, neurally-inspired sensory data preprocessor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II Project, Thalchemy researched and developed algorithms based on the properties of biological spiking neurons and the sensory processing capabilities of the human brain. Like the human brain, the neural algorithms developed during this Phase II project can accurately process information from multiple sensory modalities, learn to accurately recognize patterns of interest, operate in real time, and demonstrate a high level of power efficiency. With these algorithms, Thalchemy demonstrated recognition and detection capabilities for a number of sensor enabled applications, such as highly accurate fitness tracking, pedestrian dead reckoning, gesture recognition, and body movement tracking.  

Before this research and developement to advance the field of spiking neural networks, typically large-scale sensor data problems were solved with one of two ways: customized application specific algorithms, or Deep Learning algorithms. In the industry today, customized algorithms are the typical approach (i.e. one algorithm per activity tracked, gesture recognized, etc.), though this approach requires long development times, has high power and memory requirements, which scale with complexity of the task, and these standard approaches often fail to generalize for broad populations. Deep Learning techniques generalize well based on training data, but typically require massive amounts of computation and memory for an accurate solution, and thus are not a good fit for wearables, smart devices, and edge devices in the Internet-of-Things.  

In this Phase II Research Project, Thalchemy has proven that a minimal model based on biological spiking neurons not only can generalize well, but can be used for a broad class of sensory processing problems, and has a memory and compute footprint that outperforms a vast majority of customized application-specific algorithms. During this research project, Thalchemy determined the minimum set of biological features that need to be included in these neural algorithms, including:

  • Leaky integrate-and-fire neurons
  • Biological timescales, operating on the order of milliseconds
  • Sparse neural connectivity
  • Modeling of variable axonal delays
  • Digital/binary representation of spikes

Thus, the approach of biology, using highly efficient spiking recurrent neural networks, is likely the best approach for solving real-time sensor processing problems.  

The broader impact of this research is that Thalchemy’s neural algorithms are capable of enabling continuous sensing applications in a wide range of energy-constrained devices like smartphones, smartwatches, wearables, and edge IoT devices. This has allowed Thalchemy’s customers and partners to improve user interfaces for their devices, provide higher accuracy quantified self for end customers, and improve user safety with features like user-fall detection. Other benefits include more accurate and lower latency body and head tracking for Virtual Reality devices and user-tracking without GPS (i.e. Pedestrian Dead Reckoning). Ultimately, the research conducted in this Phase II project has demonstrated that spiking neural networks are a highly accurate and low power algorithm, which can be deployed to handle a wide range of real-time sensor data processing tasks.
